title: Have you ever shot someone? - Quora

response.answer_text: Rifle Team Match Dickinson College vs Penn State, 1963–64 season Location: U.S. Army War College, Carlisle Barracks, Carlisle, PA I was preparing to go to the firing line, checking my equipment one last time. My Anschutz .22 caliber match rifle was in perfect condition, its hooked butt plate adjusted for the prone position, sling attached, palm rest in my bag, ammo neatly arranged in the holder to ensure I fired exactly ten rounds, no more, no less, at the first targets. Now it was time to prepare myself, slipping into the meditative state that would lower my resting pulse rate to 55 beats per minute. I sat down, breathing slowly and evenly. “Hamilton, lets talk outside!” Crap! It was Sergeant Greenwalt, breaking my concentration… I exited onto the front step. “O.K., We have never beaten Penn State. Ever. But today we have a chance. Reid is firing on this relay, and he’s smokin’! We’re only down a few points and we can make them up in the final relay, but you’ve got a job to do.” “I’ll do my best, Sergeant!” “I know you’ll shoot your best, but you've gotta do one more thing for me. I’ve put you in the final relay, in Lane One. I’ve put Penn State’s number one shooter in Lane Ten. “I want you to shoot him in the leg.” “Huh?” “Remember that accident Gerow had last week?” I remembered it very well. Gerow was warming his rifle up, as all the shooters did before sighting in. We would fire the first ten or twelve rounds as fast as we could into the backstop. They would ricochet safely downward into the dirt, Those first shots would heat the rifle barrel, distorting it slightly. We would then sight in with a warm barrel, accommodating the distortion. Without that, we would not have the necessary pin-point accuracy. Well, Gerow didn’t control his rifle while warming up. While firing randomly into the backstop, he allowed the muzzle to drift to the right. He was firing from Lane One, but his rounds were impacting around Lane Four. No problem so far…. He also let his muzzle drift upward, so instead of shooting horizontally into the lower backstop, he shot high, hitting near the top. Problem…! When he pulled the trigger his shot hit high and right at lane Four, then deflected low and right. hitting the shooter on Lane Ten in the left thigh. “Oww! I’ve been shot” “Cease fire, cease fire! We checked him out. No real damage done that time. We were firing standard velocity match grade .22 ammunition. The soft bullet lost considerable speed during the ricochet, and hit a denim-covered leg. We found the spent round on the floor next to Anderson, the shooter on Ten. A bruise, but no penetration. It was easy to reconstruct the accident. The backstop had recently been painted, and the new paint had a clear chip taken out. The physics were clear. We laid down a sandbag on Ten, and I re-enacted the shot. Bullseye! “I want you to shoot him in the leg. Shake him up! Get him off his game! Mess up his score! Can you do that?” I grinned. “Yes sir! “Just remember; time your shots. Shoot when the Penn State guy beside you shoots and you won’t be identified as the source.” I knew that…. Sgt. Greenwalt and I were both country boys. We were raised with guns, and knew how to use them as tools as well as weapons. We had also tested our limits as kids and young adults. He trusted me to take the shot and I was confident I could do it. We never even considered the potential downside. My rotation was called. I took my place on Lane One. “Ready on the right! Ready on the left! Ready on the firing line!” “Commence firing!” Bang! Bang! Bang! “Shit!” Bang! “Cease fire!” The Penn State shooter was grabbing at his leg. “I’ve been stung by a bee!” he shouted to his coach. “No you haven’t, Son,” the coach replied, picking up a spent round from the floor. “You’ve been hit!” There was a brief discussion; no blood, no foul. The coaches agreed it was a freak accident. “Ready on the right! Ready on the left! Ready on the firing line!” “Commence firing!” Bang! Bang! Bang! Bang! “Shit!” “Cease fire!” Another spent round on the floor. Another bruise. Another discussion. “Commence firing!” Three minutes passed. The sound of firing became sporadic, as shooters concentrated on their aim. Then… Bang! Bang! “Dammit again!” I just had to get in that last ding. I really felt that I was messing up his score. If two were good, three would be better. ***** My score that day was good… one of my best for the season. The Penn State guy in Lane Ten… a personal best! He truly had nerves of steel. The final score for the match? I don’t remember the exact numbers, but we lost by the smallest margin of the season. Afterword: As a late adolescent male, I returned to campus feeling very full of myself. What I had just done felt like the ultimate “cops and robbers” game (I guess today’s analogy would be to a video game). I had done something considered taboo, but with the consent (suggestion) of my coach. I felt good! I met my girlfriend for dinner at the Student Center… couldn’t wait to tell her all about my “heroics.” She set me straight. Very straight. Wouldn’t even talk to me for two weeks. But first, she said all the things my mother would have said (including “You could have shot his eye out!.”) but I listened to her. If you ask me now, I’ll tell you it was a stupid idea. But using the judgement of a college age male….
Yes. Several times on several occasions. Normally while being attacked. I’d prefer not to detail the instances as the for legal aspects.
